title: Installing devDependencies does not update shrinkwrap
body:
I've created a shrink-wrap using `npm shrinkwrap --dev`. Installing new dependencies (`npm i -S express`) correctly updates the `npm-shrinkwrap.json`. However, installing a devDependency (`npm i -D eslint@1`) does **not** update the `npm-shrinkwrap.json`.

This seems counterintuitive as we've specified we want everything shrinkwrapped so you would expect `npm-shrinkwrap.json` to always be updated. To get around this at the moment we have to always remember to do `npm shrinkwrap --dev` after installing a new devDependency. Also, when updating a dependency with something like `npm i -D eslint@2` the `npm-shrinkwrap.json` is not updated either, which is probably even worse as it's already specified in the `npm-shrinkwrap.json`! :fearful:

This is with `npm@3.8.0`.

title: Cat does't work with windows wild cards
body:
I have the following file structure:

|-package.json
|-output/
|-Client/
|------ js/
|-------- component1/
|---------------------------one.css 
|---------------------------one.js 
|---------component2/
|---------------------------two.css 
|---------------------------two.js 

The package.json and Client directory are in the same root directory.
I want to cat all the css files into a single css file.

Here is my Package.json:
  "scripts": {
    		"cat-css": "cat Client/js/*.css > output/styles.css"
  },

When I run npm run cat-css I get the following error:

Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open 'C:\dev\somefolder\somefolder\somefolder\Client\js\*.css'
    at Error (native)

I'm ruining it on Windows. Perhaps there is something wrong with the wild card?

[npm-debug.txt](https://github.com/npm/npm/files/152765/npm-debug.txt)

body:

I am encountering issues with installing a private package after publishing it successfully. I can't understand what's going on here and I've tried running the same thing on a different machine with the same Node/NPM setup.

The first time I published this package, everything worked fine - then I updated the package and republished. Now not even the first package that I had published is working, and is showing me the same error as the below:

title: `--depth Infinity` has no effect on `npm update`
body:
I have a package `package-a`, which depends on `package-b`, which depends on `package-c`.

I'm working in `package-a`, and all the commands here are run from its root directory (with its `package.json`). 
For this example, lets say that `package-b` depends on `"package-c": "^1.0.0"`. I have `v1.0.0` of `package-c` currently installed in `node_modules/`, and there's a `v1.0.1` of `package-c` published to npm.

Based on the docs (https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/update), I would expect `npm --depth Infinity update` to install `package-c@1.0.1`, but it doesn't. After running `npm --depth Infinity update`, I am left with `package-c@1.0.0` installed in my `node_modules` directory.

Other things I've tried:
- `npm update` does not install a new version of `package-c`. This is what I expect based on the docs.
- `npm --depth 9999 update` _does_ install the new version of `package-c`, which is also what I'd expect. I see that the docs were changed in https://github.com/npm/npm/pull/11150 to recommend `--depth Infinity` instead of `--depth 9999`, but as mentioned above `--depth Infinity` does not seem to work.

Tested on `npm@3.8.0`.

title: Feature request: packages naming
body:
Hi all, I've tried to search in the issues, but I don't know how call this "feature".

A lot of little modules approach is better than some big modules approach, but the problem of the *"little modules approach"* is that you need to nominate these, and you will need **a lot** of names!
So, I'm not a god of math, but is very easy that two people want to give the **same name** to different packages.

So my question is:
Why npm don't have / don't adopt a different packages naming?
A good example could be **username/package**.
So after publish a package named *foo*, I can install it by typing
```
npm install delvedor/foo
```
or if I want the *otherUser* foo package
```
npm install otheUser/foo
```

It was already proposed?
- If not, do you think could be a good idea? Why?
- If yes, where?

Thanks.

title: Package installation via github fails silently if package name doesn't match
body:
Hi,

I just wanted to install a package with the following `package.json`:

```json
{
  "private": true,
  "dependencies": {
    "matchMedia": "github:paulirish/matchMedia.js"
  }
}
```

This doesn't work, as the package name was changed in the meantime to `matchmedia-polyfill`. But if I run `npm install` with this `package.json`, I just get… nothing.

No package, but no error message either. Just nothing:


```bash
$ npm install

$
```

I would suggest to show an error message in case the package name doesn't match the found `package.json` in the git repository?

title: npm run fails on Windows when command contains "./"
body:
I'm working on a project with a team of mixed operating systems (Windows, Linux, Mac) and our package.json has a few `npm run` definitions that include the dot-slash notation for executing a binary:

```
    ...
    "prod": "./scripts/build.sh",
    "test": "./scripts/test.sh",
    ...
```

When I try to run these commands in my git bash shell in Windows, I get this error:

```
$ npm run test

> ...@0.0.1 test C:\Users\...
> ./scripts/test.sh

'.' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.

npm ERR! Windows_NT 10.0.10586
npm ERR! argv "C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\node.exe" "C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\node_modules\\npm\\bin\\npm-cli.js" "run" "test"
npm ERR! node v5.5.0
npm ERR! npm  v3.7.0
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! ...@0.0.1 test: `./scripts/test.sh`
npm ERR! Exit status 1
```

The dot-slash notation works just fine when run directly in the shell, so this is an issue with npm.

title: Error: EPERM, chown '/[WORKING DIR]/node_modules/[PACKAGE NAME]/package.json'
body:
This is an old issue that likely was never solved, e.g. in https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/7563 or https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/6905, usually addressed by the very kind @smikes . 

I need to use node 0.12.x and its latest associated npm to be as close as possible to a deployment environment I can't control (Gandi.net's basic hosting). To be able to use an old node, I test my code in a clean Docker container with the latest Debian and node 0.12.x from nodesource. 

The installation of npm packages however always fails with something that looks like the console output below. Remember that all of this runs as root.

```
root@3adc90053544:/opt# npm install
npm WARN package.json dicoim-main-website@0.0.1 No README data
npm ERR! tar.unpack untar error /root/.npm/express/4.13.4/package.tgz
npm ERR! Linux 4.1.18-boot2docker
npm ERR! argv "/usr/bin/node" "/usr/bin/npm" "install"
npm ERR! node v0.12.10
npm ERR! npm  v2.14.9
npm ERR! path /opt/node_modules/express/package.json
npm ERR! code EPERM
npm ERR! errno -1

npm ERR! Error: EPERM, chown '/opt/node_modules/express/package.json'
npm ERR!     at Error (native)
npm ERR!  { [Error: EPERM, chown '/opt/node_modules/express/package.json']
npm ERR!   errno: -1,
npm ERR!   code: 'EPERM',
npm ERR!   path: '/opt/node_modules/express/package.json',
npm ERR!   fstream_finish_call: 'chown',
npm ERR!   fstream_type: 'File',
npm ERR!   fstream_path: '/opt/node_modules/express/package.json',
npm ERR!   fstream_class: 'FileWriter',
npm ERR!   fstream_stack: 
npm ERR!    [ '/usr/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/fstream/lib/writer.js:306:21',
npm ERR!      '/usr/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/graceful-fs/polyfills.js:210:7',
npm ERR!      'FSReqWrap.oncomplete (fs.js:95:15)' ] }
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Please try running this command again as root/Administrator.

npm ERR! Please include the following file with any support request:
npm ERR!     /opt/npm-debug.log
root@3adc90053544:/opt
```

Because this is a Debian image prepared for Docker, I'm already running this as root and there's not even a _sudo_ command available. ```npm cache clean``` achieves nothing. The cache is in ```/root/.npm```. The full _npm-debug.log_ is at https://gist.github.com/giacecco/8504d2e8501b59f610d9 .

I used node in Docker systems before without ever finding this issue, this is why I presume it is related to 0.x versions of node and was solved eventually in later versions. But is there a workaround for older versions?

Thanks.

title: Error installing meanio.
body:
Hi, i tried installing meanio using

npm install -g meanio

and

npm install -g meanio@latest

Both both throw me the error as shown.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12254813/13378053/2d787020-de31-11e5-995e-204c1624d6a7.png)

I tried reinstalling node and npm, and now use NVM to update to latest version of node and npm and it still doesnt work.

Anyone have any ideas? :)

title: npm install -g git+ssh://.... problem
body:
This seems to be a variant of https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/9679 but with global installs.

Run `npm install -g git+ssh://....`.

Then run `npm -g outd`.

Fails with `Unsupported URL Type: ssh://...`

Does not repro with non-global installs.

Log (redacted):
```
40 verbose stack Error: Unsupported URL Type: ssh://...
40 verbose stack     at parseUrl (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/npm-package-arg/npa.js:169:13)

44 error node v5.6.0
45 error npm  v3.8.0 
```

title: ls: Do not set process.exitCode when ls is executed during the unbuild phase
body:
Prevents invalid error status when `npm install --production <module>` is used.
Fixes: #11699

My thinking behind this is that `ls` is purely informational when executed as part of an `npm install` (in the unbuild phase). It shouldn't be responsible for deciding if the install should fail (i.e. shouldn't set the process exit code).

When you execute it via `npm ls <package>` (etc.) then it's valid that it may exit with a failure code if `<package>` is not found (the existing behaviour).

title: npm install -production failing since 3.7.4 for all modules (OSX and Linux)
body:
I've been having an error when using `npm install` using the `-production` flag since updating npm to 3.7.5, I've rolled back to 3.7.4 and still see the issue (tested on both OSX and Ubuntu). No debug log is written. 3.7.3 is working correctly.

npm correctly installs the module but immediately before exiting (with return code 1) logs: `npm ERR! code 1`.

I've setup my environment and run a test installing lodash (the same occurs with all modules I've tried) as such:
```bash
rm -rf /tmp/npm-test ~/.npm
mkdir /tmp/npm-test
cd /tmp/npm-test
npm init -y
npm install -production -verbose lodash 2> install.log
```

My `~/.npmrc` contains only:
```
//registry.npmjs.org/:_authToken=<token>
```

The log from 3.7.3: https://gist.github.com/ixalon/bbba9547787f4d356f5a
The log from 3.7.4: https://gist.github.com/ixalon/260011abf364889a2e76

The diff between the resulting two logs shows nothing significant other than the final outcome:
```diff
diff v3.7.3.log v3.7.4.log
```

title: npm completion does not work with :
body:
I have the following scripts `copy` `copy:all` `copy:js` `copy:css`

I have added the completion script.

If I type `npm run copy:<tab>` It completes to `npm run copy:copy:`

Also if I run `npm run copy:cs<tab>` it completes to `npm run copy:copy:css`
